title: Use the scale as the tick key function.
body:
Previously we were using string coercion as the key function for axis ticks. However, when the stringified value of the tick does not fully capture the representation (such as a date with millisecond precision, whose string form only has second precision; fixes #1529), string coercion is insufficient.

Fortunately, there is an equivalently-simple key function for tick identity: the scale! If the scale does not return a unique position for the given tick, then the tick would be overlapping, so it serves perfectly as the key function.

title: Fix point-in-polygon for multiple polar rings.
body:
Instead of detecting if any single polygon ring winds around a pole, we
consider the cumulative winding of all polygon rings together.  This is
consistent with the area calculation, which considers the cumulative
area total of all rings.

This fixes #1521: an issue with the Hammer Retroazimuthal projection,
which uses such a polygon with two rings, covering most of the globe.

In addition, drop the special handling of points at the south pole,
which might have been there to pass an incorrect test: a CCW triangle
touching the south pole, which was probably incorrectly thought to be
clockwise.  This fixes an issue with a “stripe” polygon rotated so that
a point is at the south pole, mentioned in #1453.

title: d3.index
Added `padding` to `d3.layout.pie`
body:
This is very handy instead of using `stroke-width`, which diminishes the visual value of small arcs in a pie/donut chart, and might intersect with other shapes in the chart. The spacing that each arc gets does not count against its value.

Example:

``` javascript
pie = d3.layout.pie()
        .spacing(2 * Math.PI * 0.01); //Each arc gets a spacer of 1% of the circle's size after it
```

![Example](http://i.imgur.com/jiUk48t.png)

title: Truncate non-integers for integer format.
body:
Instead of ignoring any non-integer floats, we truncate so that small
floating point precision errors don’t affect integer formatting.  This
is consistent with Python’s "%d" format.

title: Round step value in d3_scale_linearTickRange to fixed precision to prevent rounding issues on Windows Phone devices
body:
The following issue occured on a HTC Windows Phone 8S running the latest version of Windows Phone 8. 

When using the function Math.pow, the resulting values are slightly off the correct values for specific input parameters. That means while Math.pow(10,0), Math.pow(10,2) or Math.pow(10,3) correctly return 1, 0.01 and 0.001, Math.pow(10,1) results in 0.09999999999999 instead of 0.1. You can test this behaviour here (with an appropriate device): http://jsbin.com/IbEvAKO/1

I could only reproduce this issue on the HTC Windows Phone 8S but other Windows Phone devices or smartphones in general might be vulnerable to this issue.

The difference between the correct and the returned value might seem minor, but it somehow breaks parts of d3 which use the ticks of linear scales, e.g. axis. If axis lie within a range where the Math.pow value is off, the axis ticks will not be displayed at all.

My proposed fix just converts the step value to a fixed size string and then back to Number. Because the step value is always an exponentiation with a base of 10, no precision is lost during the conversion.

title: Remove dead code.
body:
This line doesn’t appear to do anything useful, since the parent node is
now saved in the closure.  Previously, this line checked to see if
target.parentNode was null, since this would cause a crash when
computing the relative position.

title: Fix d3.mouse touch fallback for HTML targets.
If present, use changedTouches[0] for d3.mouse.
body: Normally d3.mouse(this) is equivalent to d3.touches(this)[0] because the clientX and clientY properties of the event and the first touch are the same. However, on touchend the touches list is empty, and the clientX and clientY are 0! So instead it seems safer to use the position of the first changed touch for the default location of a touch event.

title: fix voronoi degenerate check (alternate)
body: After thinking about it a little bit, this seems like a better base case.  Though I still don't really know what's happening here.

title: fix voronoi degenerate polygon check
body:
To be honest I'm not exactly sure what's going on here, but this does seem like a valid guard for the code below, and it sure seemed to clear up my problem.

Let me know if I can add anything else or if this isn't a valid fix.

title: Fix spurious touchmove without touchstart.
body: Fixes #1497. Because we listen to touchmove and touchend events on the window, whereas touchstart events are restricted to the targeted element, it was possible to receive a touchmove event for a new touch that started outside the targeted element without first receiving its touchstart event. The fix is to put the temporary touchstart listener during the gesture on the window, like the touchmove and touchend events. We also use a capturing listener and temporarily disable the touchstart listener on the target to prevent duplicate touchstart events from being received.

title: Support simultaneous zooming on multiple targets.
body:
Fixes #1497, where a zoom gesture would break if a touch was started
outside the target during a gesture.

Each zoom gesture now only considers touches that were started on its
associated target element.  This allows multiple zoom gestures to occur
at once without conflicts.

title: Support parsing timezone offsets.
body:
Note that the resulting Date object can only be in the local timezone
(or UTC), due to the limitations of JavaScript Dates.

Fixes #1494.

title: Remove component.json to avoid bower warnings
body:
Bower gives the advice to switch from component.json to bower.json.
When installing the package through "bower install" or "bower update" bower outputs warnings if the repository config hasn't been migrated from components.json to bower.json

bower fetching d3
bower checking out d3#v3.1.10
bower warn Package d3 is still using the deprecated "component.json" file

title: Remove major class from axis ticks.
body: The major class is now obsolete with the removal of tick subdivision. Fixes #1485.

title: Fix #1483; time parsing with padding modifier.
d3.geo.circle: ensure coincident start/end points.
body:
Due to floating point rounding error, d3.geo.circle would sometimes miss
out the end point, which should be coincident with the start point.

Fixes #1476.

title: Fix clipExtent intersection sorting.
body:
The generic polygon clipping algorithm requires intersection points to
be sorted in a clockwise order around the clip edge.  Previously, the
intersection points for 2D clipping in d3_geo_clipView were sorted in a
counterclockwise direction in screen pixels, probably because the
flipped y-axis in screen pixels was not being taken into account.

title: Zoom Transitions
body:
Example: http://bl.ocks.org/mbostock/06ecebbae5be9665e995

My biggest concern is dispatching zoom events on the initial application of the zoom behavior. This could easily break old code because the listener may not be ready to receive zoom events at the time the behavior is applied.

For example, it is common to apply the zoom behavior to a parent element that contains elements (such as axes) whose appearance will change during zoom. If the zoom behavior dispatches zoom events on its initial render, those child elements will not yet exist and the listener will crash. It’s easy to workaround this problem by registering the zoom behavior _after_ creating those child elements (per the above example), but this change would still break old code.

(The same argument applies to the brush on its initial render, though I think it will be less common for those brush events to break anything because commonly the brush is drawn on top of, and thus _after_, elements that are affected by the brush state.)

On the other hand, a nice side-effect of zoom events on initial application is that you eliminate code duplication between enter (the initial display) and update (in response to subsequent user events). But this is a negligible benefit as you could easily eliminate that code duplication by calling the zoom event listener explicitly on enter.

Potential fixes:
1. We could defer dispatch of events on application one tick by using d3.timer. This would guarantee that child elements have been created, however it is undesirable because it would cause flickering on the initial display.
2. We could not emit zoom events (and likewise brush events) when the zoom behavior is initially applied (and likewise whenever the brush is applied via selection.call). However, this would arguably be inconsistent with the automatic emission of events during transitions, and would require the caller to do more work during initialization.
3. We could special-case just the first application of the zoom behavior (and likewise the brush) to not emit events. But, this feels like an overly specialized fix.

title: Fix brush rounding.
body:
The use of floor appeared to cause minor inconsistencies in the position
of brush edges for different positions along a scale.  I believe floor
was originally used to ensure the brush would display more crisply.

Using round would be an alternative fix.  However, removing any kind of
rounding in pixel-space ensures that transitioning an extent (set in
data-space) will finish with the correct extent, determined by inverting
the pixel-space extent.

Of course, there may be a small precision error introduced by inverting
the pixel-space extent, which we may also want to address anyway, in
which case I suppose we could still use round.

title: 3.3 “Haleakalā”
body:
- [x] decide whether brush should dispatch events automatically during selection / transition (see discussion in #1461)
- [x] decide whether brush should store pre-transition state via closure or DOM (element.**chart**) [verdict: DOM]
- [x] brush should restore data-space domain (extentDomain) on transition end
- [x] implement an example of discrete brushing (snapping) to verify event design ([6232537](http://bl.ocks.org/mbostock/6232537), [6232620](http://bl.ocks.org/mbostock/6232620))
- [x] decide whether brush should floor extent ([Jason’s comment](https://github.com/mbostock/d3/pull/1460#issuecomment-22672968)) or rely on shape-rendering crispEdges
- [x] support transitions for the zoom behavior
- [x] investigate supporting smooth zooming for zoom behavior transitions (requires knowing viewport size?)
- [x] zoomstart should interrupt zoom transition
- [x] dynamic client-side simplification example ([6245977](http://bl.ocks.org/mbostock/6245977), [6252418](http://bl.ocks.org/mbostock/6252418))
- [x] decide whether to add d3.geo.simplify or expose d3_geo_streamTransform [verdict: d3.geo.transform]
- [x] a demo that composes viewport clipping and simplification ([6252418](http://bl.ocks.org/mbostock/6252418))
- [x] add d3.pairs?
- [x] add d3.geo.compose, or reconsider how to combine custom transforms and viewport clipping… feels like d3.geo.identity is a bit of a misnomer since the only reason it exists (versus just using null) is to apply viewport clipping to an identity transform. but sometimes you want to apply that to a custom transform, and it feels cumbersome to do that currently [verdict: no d3.geo.compose for now, but rename d3.geo.identity to d3.geo.clipExtent]
- [x] fix #1434 (time.nice and time.ticks)

title: Add brush transitions.
body: Fixes #1385. [Example.](http://bl.ocks.org/mbostock/2dba4bdf7b4147ae298b)

title: Fix #1453 - spurious interpolate when clean.
body: It looks to me like the d3_geo_clip polygonEnd check is assuming that if there are no clipped segments that the input polygon is outside (and possibly surrounding) the viewport. However, the clipped segments can also be empty when the polygon is completely inside the viewport, in which case the listener was already sent the input polygon (clean & 1). This check prevents additional interpolation when there was no intersection.

title: Add zoomstart and zoomend events. Fixes #1422.
Fix #1397 - add beforesend event to d3.xhr.
Fix #1435 - use ten ticks by default.
body: This applies to linear.ticks and linear.tickFormat, and their equivalents on pow and sqrt scales. In addition it changes the behavior of linear.nice() so that it is equivalent to linear.nice(10) for consistency.
